repnme.cdata!:
Uganda Decentralized Services Delivery : a
            Makerere University Training Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Uganda Decentralized
            Services Delivery Makerere University Training Pilot Project
            were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: national universities in
            Africa are an under-used resource for the critical task of
            government capacity development; programs enlisting the
            intellectual resources of universities for government
            capacity building in Africa can stimulate positive change
            within the universities themselves, and lead to increased
            relevance and quality of education; local government
            officials benefit from intensified interaction with
            educational institutions on many level; public officials,
            upon completion of long-term training, will return to their
            employers; the benefits of World Bank-Foundation
            partnerships can outweigh the management costs; and
            monitoring and evaluation of the contributions of knowledge
            institutions to human capacity creation is complex and
            difficult to measure.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Decentralized Service Delivery
            (Makerere University Training Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Decentralized Service Delivery
            (Makerere University Training Pilot) Project seeks to
            support Uganda's efforts at building capacity for
            improving the quality of decentralized public services
            delivery at the local government level. Its key objective is
            to develop an effective, sustainable, and replicable
            mechanism--that is fully integrated with the
            Government's decentralization and public service reform
            programs and capacity building goals--for strengthening the
            skills and competencies of those responsible for service
            delivery and management at the local government level. There
            are four main project components. The first enhances
            academic institutional capacity by sponsoring
            custom-designed workshops and short-term courses, providing
            specialized training, and develops a resource center on
            decentralization. This component also finances an academic
            decision-making mechanism; provides interns with exposure to
            employment opportunities in districts; and funds project
            support. The second component funds pilot support to local
            universities for local government capacity building through
            curriculum development, establishing a fund for innovative
            excellence, and supporting a local government staff training
            pilot and planning unit. The third component enhances
            decentralization policy research and formulation capacity.
            The fourth component focuses on general performance
            monitoring and learning from the pilots by testing changes
            in the academic environment as well as in service delivery
